item.desc: A commercial agent
The terms used in the texts include ‘worker’ and ‘factor’

This term has been seen once, describing someone we know is a servant, so it seems that this is probably a household role rather than the keeper of an inn; but we should keep an eye on how it is used if it reappears, and how it relates to the occupation of ale brewer
This occupation is specifically for uses of the term ‘apothecary’ (or in Forman often ‘poticary’) or its similar Latin forms. For now we are keeping the term ‘drugger’ separate (qv)
A dealer in spirits
For the terms ‘aqua vitæ man’ or ‘aqua vitæ seller’; if we see more references to people who deal in spirits, using other terminology, we may want to revisit the name of this occupation
For the term ‘lecturer’
For use when an entry describes someone as being ‘attendant upon’ a master or mistress; the accompanying relation is servant
A lawyer who practised in courts of common law

Also known as an attorney-at-law (sometimes referred to in texts as ‘attorney in law’). More general references to lawyers should be given the occupation ‘Lawyer’, and note that ‘Solicitor’ is also an occupation.
This often appears in texts as ‘baylie’ or some variant on that spelling
Including the term ‘outward barrister’.
A household servant who arranges a bed and bedclothes ready for use
Including ‘servant boy’, ‘boy’, ‘lad’
A worker with brass.
This has been encountered spelled ‘Brasyer’.
For the bursar or treasurer of an institution, and appearing in entries as ‘bowser’. For a ship’s purser see that occupation below.
The officer of a household responsible for buying provisions
The term Napier uses is ‘cater’, typically spelled ‘kater’, but the words ‘cater’ and ‘caterer’ were interchangeable in this period

This will soon be removed from the list and should not be used. The occupation ‘Cutler’ can sometimes be written so as to look like ‘catler’. The occupation ‘Cowherd’ should be used for people who are employed to keep cattle.

This has been used to date for a civic officer. If we come across a chamberlain of a household we may want to create a new occupation. Note also that the ‘Lord Chamberlain’ should be given that title as a roleName and not ‘Chamberlain’ as an occupation.
Including ‘chamber maiden’
A woman carrying out domestic chores for a daily rate (rather than as an employee of the household)
This has been encountered spelled ‘chearewoman’
Someone who makes and/or sells cheese

The relationship between the occupations ‘Cheese man’ and ‘Cheesemonger’ is tricky to determine, so for now the occupation ‘Cheese man’ should be reserved for when that term is explicitly used in an entry. If other terms or expressions are encountered we can reassess how we distinguish these two occupations.
Someone who sells or deals in cheese

The relationship between the occupations ‘Cheesemonger’ and ‘Cheese man’ is tricky to determine, so for now the occupation ‘Cheesemonger’ should be reserved for when that term is explicitly used in an entry. If other terms or expressions are encountered we can reassess how we distinguish these two occupations.
A household officer in charge of the kitchen’s records and accounts
The word kitchen is sometimes spelled ‘citchen’ or ‘citching’
An officer of the court who prepares indictments, keeps court records and advises Justices of the Peace
A menial servant who carries coal
Someone who makes or mends shoes
We may decide that this and shoemaker should be combined, for now we’re keeping them separate
This term may mean someone who makes charcoal or who takes it to market to sell, or it can mean someone who works in a coal mine
Use this occupation for the term ‘collier’ itself (however spelled); we may be able to refine the definition if we see further information about how Napier is using the word
A maker of sweetmeats

It is currently unclear precisely what this means or whether it indicates one occupation or a range of occupations. According to the Oxford English Dictionary, at this date it might be referring to the governor or warden of a royal fortress or castle, a military officer, or an officer of the peace, either generally or specifically a High Constable (an officer of a hundred or other large administrative district) or a Parish Constable (an officer of a parish or township). Note that to date, men described as ‘High Constable’ have been given that as a roleName but not ‘Constable’ as an occupation. We have had no instances of ‘Parish Constable’ to date, but that would presumably be dealt with (mutatis mutandis) as we have ‘High Constable’ and be given a roleName but not an occupation. Because of the possible confusion about all of this, these decisions may need to be revisited later on when we have more examples to work with.
This has been encountered in a variant form, ‘crowner’
A legal adviser
As in ‘counsellor-at-law’
This covers anyone employed to look after cattle, whether described as ‘cowherd’ in the entry, or by some other term such as ‘cattlekeeper’

For now, this should only be used where the term ‘cunning man’ is employed in the entry; we have ‘soothsayer’ as a separate occupation and may need to add more as we encounter new words and expressions
A leather worker
We have one example of this to date (in CASE17485), provided that that does not turn out to be a creative spelling of ‘carrier’ (qv)
Note that this list also includes the similar-looking ‘cutter’.
A tailor who measures and cuts cloth
Note that this list also includes the similar-looking ‘cutler’.
It is worth noting that Napier is likely to spell this ‘deary man’
Sometimes given as ‘stiller’

As in the term for medical practitioner, explicitly used, not as in the title, possessor of DD, etc. This means that ‘Mr Smith, a doctor’ should be given the occupation ‘Doctor’, but ‘Dr Smith’ should not, even if it is clear from context that Dr Smith is a medical practitioner. It is worth being very wary of this word: we have at least one instance of someone described in the form ‘Thomas Smith, doctor’ turning out to be the possessor of a law degree and not a medical practitioner. In fact, it is comparatively unusual in this period to see this term (rather than for instance ‘physician’ and ‘surgeon’) used as the description of someone’s occupation.
Note that we also have linen draper and woollen draper as distinct occupations
For people specifically referred to using this term. Where the term ‘apothecary’ is employed in the text, that occupation should be used instead

This should be used for anyone explicitly described as a ‘farmer’ in the text; more typically Napier uses the words ‘husbandman’ and ‘yeoman’ (or ‘yeoman husbandman’), more specific terms, and for those the corresponding occupations should be used
Someone who shoes horses; sometimes farriers were responsible for treating horses’ diseases
The relationship between this, ‘Blacksmith’ and ‘Smith’ may need disentangling at some point. For now, the occupation should be chosen according to the particular term used in the entry.
Someone who deals in hides and pelts or who prepares them for the tanner
A dealer in glassware
Typically occurring in entries as ‘glassman’ or ‘glass man’
So far encountered as ‘glasier’ and distinct from ‘glass-man’, which has its own occupation
Including ‘stable groom’
This includes anyone described as the ‘warden’, ‘master’ or ‘president’ of a college, where the term means the head of the college
A person who treats horses
This has been used for someone described in an entry as a ‘knitter of stockings’
Note that ‘yeoman husbandman’ has its own occupation below.
The keeper of an inn, a house providing lodgings as well as food and drink (unlike a victualling-house)

We currently have several different terms for someone who keeps a public house (taverner, innkeeper, victualler), and it is unclear as yet whether they are being used interchangeably or to mean distinct things. For now the safest course is to use the term employed in the entry and we can revisit the issue later on. The inn’s name is often given; record this in a comment tag with PLACE in case we can encode it later on.

‘Justice’ (‘justiciarius’ in Latin) is a broad term that can refer to a judge, a magistrate, or a justice of the peace. If a more specific term is used, ‘Judge’ and ‘Magistrate’ are available as alternative occupations and should be preferred. So far ‘Justice of the Peace’ has been treated as a roleName added after the surname.
If the person is keeper of the King’s (or Queen’s) Park then that full title should be added as roleName, but ‘Keeper’ still supplied as occupation
This has been encountered once so far, to someone serving a bishop, hence its inclusion as an occupation rather than using roleName
Someone who hand-delivers secret or sensitive documents to or from the monarch
The king should also be added to listPerson and a relation of messenger between them.
Note that the word ‘kitchen’ has been encountered in the forms ‘citching’ (looking very like ‘cilching’), ‘cutchen’ and ‘citchen’
Note that the word ‘kitchen’ has been encountered in the forms ‘citching’ (looking very like ‘cilching’), ‘cutchen’ and ‘citchen’
For use of the general term ‘labourer’. If the word ‘workman’ is used, that occupation should be employed instead, and if the term ‘day labourer’ is used then there is a specific occupation for that
Note that ‘Bone lace maker’ is classified separately
Someone who does laundry for more than one person or household, for payment
Covering terms ‘launderer’, ‘laundress’, ‘washerwoman’; for a household servant responsible for laundry see instead ‘laundry-maid’
A domestic servant responsible for household laundry
Where the reference is instead to someone who does laundry for various people for a fee, the occupation ‘Launderer’ should be used
For use when someone is explicitly described as a lawyer; solicitor and attorney are more specialised forms of laywer and have their own occupations
A man employed for singing in a cathedral or college chapel
The term encountered so far in the casebooks is ‘singing clarke’, for someone at Magdalen College (Oxford)
This seems to be an assistant’s job at a mill
Including ‘maidservant’, ‘maid servant’ and ‘servant maid’; also ‘wench’

For someone described as ‘X’s man’, ‘X’s manservant’ or ‘X’s serving man’. Note that this term should not be used for people of particularly high status (those given the title ‘Mr’ and above). Within the casebooks we find two overlapping but distinct senses of ‘servant’ (and related terms): an older sense in which society is hierarchical and everyone serves someone else all the way up to the monarch; and a newer sense in which the term ‘servant’ denotes a person doing a particular low-status job. To deal with these different meanings of the term, we use the relation servant for service at all levels of society, but do not use the occupations ‘Servant’, ‘Man (Servant)’, or similar, for high-status people. Thus if an entry describes Mr X as Sir YZ’s man, or Sir YZ as Lord AB’s man, then the relation servant should be used to link them but the occupation ‘Man (Servant)’ omitted.
Someone responsible for buying provisions for a college, Inn of Court, or other group of people
A general term for someone who tends horses, possibly in particular one who treats their diseases
A worker or dealer in metal
This has been used where the expression itself appeared in an entry. Where a more specific term is employed, we also have the occupations ‘Blacksmith’ and ‘Ironmonger’, and can add more as necessary.

While this may simply mean a servant to a miller, there is a significant possibility that it designates a distinct occupation of its own (an assistant of some sort), so this is recorded as a distinct occupation. A miller should also be added to listPerson and the relationship servant between them.
Someone who builds or repairs mills

In the ecclesiastical sense. Includes ‘pastor’, ‘parson’ and ‘priest’, but rectors and vicars are to be given those specific occupations instead. The parish is often given: record this in a comment tag with PLACE in case we can encode it later on.
This has appeared in one entry to date; we do not (yet) know what it means
The officer (servant) in charge of a large household’s bread or its pantry (where the bread was kept)
Including ‘pasturer’, ‘servant to keep his pastures’, ‘pastur keeper’
A gentleman-at-arms; an attendant or guard, typically to the monarch
Where it is specified in the entry that the person is a pensioner ‘to the king’ (or similar), the tag relation name="pensioner" should also be used
This has appeared once to date: a ‘digger of a pit’. Perhaps a gravedigger or a miner.

While this may simply mean a servant to a plumber, there is a significant possibility that it designates a distinct occupation of its own (an assistant of some sort, or plumber’s mate), so this is recorded as a distinct occupation. A plumber should also be added to listPerson and the relationship servant between them.
Covering both poulterer and poulteress
The preservator of a wood or forest regularly looked through the trees in his care to certify any branches or trees that had fallen
Not to be confused with the ship’ purser, which has a separate entry.
A junior ecclesiastic, responsible for reading parts of the service
A treasurer, responsible for overseeing the collection of rents and other money due to a landowner or the Crown
In this period the terms ‘register’ and ‘registrar’ are interchangeable
Including ‘servant retainer’; the relation name value should also be retainer. Note that retained servants do not live in, so the master’s address cannot be inferred from the servant’s.
Someone appointed to find saltpetre
A (gender-neutral) contemporary synonym for ‘saltpetre man’

This has appeared simply as ‘serjeant’ (or rather ‘serieant’). If it is given as someone’s title, and the reference is demonstrably to a serjeant-at-law rather than any other sort of sergeant (as in the case of Serjeant Yelverton, later Judge Yelverton), then this should be supplied as the occupation.

For someone explicitly described as a ‘servant’ (or Latin equivalents such as ‘puella’ and ‘serva’). Note that this term should not be used for people of particularly high status (those given the title ‘Mr’ and above). Within the casebooks we find two overlapping but distinct senses of ‘servant’: an older sense in which society is hierarchical and everyone serves someone else all the way up to the monarch; and a newer sense in which the term ‘servant’ denotes a person doing a particular low-status job. To deal with these different meanings of the term, we use the relation servant for service at all levels of society, but do not use the occupation ‘Servant’ to describe high-status people. Thus if an entry describes Mr X as serving Sir YZ, or Sir YZ is described as servant to Lord AB, then the relation servant should be used to link them but the occupation ‘Servant’ omitted.
An officer who rings the church bell, digs graves, and may be responsible for maintaining and looking after the church
Sextons are typically, but by no means exclusively, male
Spelled ‘sherman’
A shipmaster and a ship’s captain are equivalent roles, but a captain runs a military vessel and a master runs a non-military vessel
A shipmaster and a ship’s captain are equivalent roles, but a captain runs a military vessel and a master runs a non-military vessel
The officer responsible for provisions and accounts on a ship
Not to be confused with the term ‘purser’ outside a maritime context, which can mean a maker of purses and can mean the same thing as treasurer or bursar
A lawyer who practised in the Court of Equity
More general references to lawyers should be given the occupation ‘Lawyer’, and ‘Attorney’ is also a separate occupation
For entries where this specific term is used. Where for instance the term ‘cunning man’ is employed, there is a separate occupation for that.
A household officer in charge of domestic servants and expenditure, and responsible for supervising the service at his master’/mistress’s table
The deputy warden of a college.

We have a ‘College head’ occupation for the head of a college regardless of what terminology is used for that college; it may be that we will eventually need a parallel term for the deputy head of a college. For now this term should be used where an entry refers to someone as a ‘subwarden’ if another term is employed then the senior editors should be consulted.
This appears in the casebooks as ‘hogherd’, ‘hogward’ or ‘keeper of the hogs’
One who plays the tabor, a small drum played one-handed to accompany a pipe

While this may simply mean a servant to a tailor, there is a significant possibility that it designates a distinct occupation of its own (an assistant of some sort), so this is recorded as a distinct occupation. A tailor should also be added to listPerson and the relationship servant between them.
Someone who produces candles from tallow (rendered animal fat), soap, and trades in oils, ointments, sauces and other assorted items and substances
Sometimes written as ‘tapster’, sometimes as ‘topster’
The keeper of a public house where wine is sold.

We currently have several different terms for someone who keeps a public house (taverner, innkeeper, victualler), and it is unclear as yet whether they are being used interchangeably or to mean distinct things. For now the safest course is to use the term employed in the entry and we can revisit the issue later on. If the tavern’s name is given, record this in a comment tag with PLACE in case we can encode it later on.
A hawker, a peddler of goods
An assistant to a keeper

In one instance to date we have encountered someone who is specified as a keeper of a walk under someone else; there the keeper of the walk has the occupation ‘Under-keeper’ and is given the relation of under-keeperSubordinate to the person he works under, who has the occupation ‘Keeper’.
Spelled ‘vnder shrive’

‘Underwood’ is coppice wood, from smaller trees than the large timber trees, so an ‘underwood seller’ is presumably someone who sells it. The one example encountered to date looks very much like ‘seller’, but it will be worth keeping an eye out in case it is ‘feller’ and it describes someone responsible for cutting the wood from the trees.
The keeper of a victualling house, a public house providing food and drink but not lodgings (unlike an inn).

We currently have several different terms for someone who keeps a public house (taverner, innkeeper, victualler), and it is unclear as yet whether they are being used interchangeably or to mean distinct things. For now the safest course is to use the term employed in the entry and we can revisit the issue later on. If the victualling house in question is named, that information should be recorded in a comment tag with the string PLACE in case it becomes possible to encode it later on.
Including ‘gentleman’ used as an occupation/relation term, as in ‘Lord Kent’s gentleman’. This is a high-status servant, presumably a male counterpart to ‘waiting gentlewoman’ or ‘gentlewoman’.
Including ‘gentlewoman’ used as an occupation/relation term, as in ‘Lady Digby’s gentlewoman’; also ‘chambergentlewoman’: this is a high-status waiting woman
Including ‘waiting maid’, or any woman who ‘waiteth on’ someone
A worker and trader in beeswax, producing candles, tapers, torches, wax for seals and writing tablets, and sometimes for medical uses
So far encountered in entries as ‘wheeler’
Someone who makes wire by drawing hot metal through a die

For someone described as ‘X’s woman’, where the term indicates a female servant. Note that this term should not be used for people of particularly high status (those given the title ‘Mrs’ and above). Within the casebooks we find two overlapping but distinct senses of ‘servant’ (and related terms): an older sense in which society is hierarchical and everyone serves someone else all the way up to the monarch; and a newer sense in which the term ‘servant’ denotes a person doing a particular low-status job. To deal with these different meanings of the term, we use the relation servant for service at all levels of society, but do not use the occupations ‘Servant’, ‘Woman (Servant)’, or similar, for high-status people. Thus if an entry describes Mrs X as Lady YZ’s woman, then the relation servant should be used to link them but the occupation ‘Woman (Servant)’ omitted.
Someone who looks after and cuts trees in a wood to provide timber or fuel
An officer concerned with the management of timber in a wood or forest, responsible for selling it and for executing warrants to fell it
A wool merchant
Someone who packs fleeces
We are currently distinguishing this from the occupation ‘Labourer’; this should be used when the term ‘workman’ is explicitly used
A woman employed for manual work

The term ‘yeoman’ can mean a farmer who works on his own land, or a rank of servant or attendant in a large household; Anthony Viscount Montague in 1595 lists as members of the great household ‘yeomen of the great chamber’, ‘yeomen of the chamber’, ‘yeoman of the cellar’, ‘yeomen of the ewer’, ‘yoeman of the pantry’, ‘yeoman of the buttery’, ‘yeoman of the wardrobe’ and ‘yeoman waiters’. In at least one case Napier uses the word ‘yeoman’ in this second sense; if we encounter instances in which he uses it in the first sense this occupation will need to be split into two. Note that ‘yeoman of the horse’ and ‘yeoman husbandman’ have their own occupations below.
This is specifically for entries that include the phrase ‘yeoman husbandman’; where only one of these words is present, the occupations ‘Yeoman’ or ‘Husbandman’ should be used as appropriate.
